Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Cluster Computing for Artificial Intelligence-Enabled Data Analytics and Earth Systems Modeling
Award.AbstractNarration: This award will provide a computer cluster to Millersville University who will use it to integrate new computational techniques and apply them to scientific questions that have relevance over a broad range of environmental and human problems. The cluster will also provide balance to the education and training of students in the Department of Earth Sciences at Millersville University which has a strong observational research background.<br/><br/>A 16-blade server and GPU node will be acquired and installed in the existing university data center. The research team identifies multiple uses for the cluster, including weather modeling for agriculture and road weather, using numerical models to understand coronal magnetic ejections and the plasma environment, linking agricultural runoff to hypoxia events in the Chesapeake Bay, and determining the links between small-scale geologic structures and subsurface fluid flow in sedimentary basins.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Millersville University (MU) Department of Earth Sciences (DES) was funded for the acquisition of a computing cluster to support research and research training (RRT) in modeling and artificial intelligence (AI) applications for Earth systems science. The impetus for this acquisition came from our need to expand our capabilities by integrating new computational techniques and applying them to scientific questions that have relevancy over a broad range of environmental and human problems. While the DES has made progress using observational research, many ongoing research questions can benefit from integrating new computational techniques and applying them to existing data sets. Examples of the research questions that are enabled by the acquisition of this computing cluster include: using AI and high-resolution modeling to improve precipitation forecasts for agriculture and road weather; using community-based numerical models to understand solar coronal magnetic ejections and the plasma environment; determining the links between agricultural runoff and summertime hypoxia events in the Chesapeake Bay; and determining the links between small-scale geologic structures and subsurface fluid flow in sedimentary basins by pairing observational data with boundary element models. Moreover, this acquisition is enabling collaboration between the DES and other departments, so that new models and improvements to existing models can be generated. Working with the computer equipment and training on numerical models have the potential for be a game-changer for students and faculty. To date, student research experiences have been strongly weighted toward field research where undergraduate students engage in RRT involving the use of instrumentation and observing systems for in-situ field and airborne measurements to investigate scientific questions. This local computing cluster augments our robust field research opportunities by offering new computational capability that are readily accessible for undergraduate and graduate student research. This results in more research opportunities for students and helps attract and retain students from underrepresented populations in STEM, for whom studies have suggested a preference for laboratory or computational research opportunities over field projects. Additionally, this computational capability significantly benefits new programs and knowledge systems in information technology, data science, artificial intelligence, weather intelligence and risk management, economics, and space weather.
